sentence.text: We show that the protein polyubiquitination-106b-25 cluster upregulates cell cycle arrest in multiple breast cancer cell lines, representing both estrogen receptor (ER+) and triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) through direct repression of the E3 ubiquitin ligase, NEDD4L.

We further show that upregulation of NOTCH1 is necessary for TIC induction downstream of miR-106b-25 in both ER + and TNBC breast cancer cells, and that re-expression of regulation of membrane depolarization is sufficient to reverse miR106b-25-mediated NOTCH1 upregulation and TIC induction.
Further, we show for the first time that regulation of membrane depolarization expression alone is significantly associated with a better relapse-free prognosis for breast cancer patients.
Here we identify a novel mechanism of NOTCH regulation and TIC induction in breast cancer via the protein polyubiquitination-106b-25 miRNA cluster.

Importantly, we demonstrate a significant positive correlation between protein polyubiquitination-106b-25 and NOTCH1 protein, yet a significant inverse correlation between miR-106b-25 and regulation of membrane depolarization mRNA in human breast cancer, suggesting a critical role for the miR106b-25/NEDD4L/NOTCH1 axis in the disease.
